criteria.name: CAC Calculation Completeness
criteria.description: Fully-loaded CAC includes all S&M costs (salaries, tools, overhead). Channel-level breakdown provided.

scale.1: Missing major costs (e.g., sales salaries). No channel breakdown. CAC severely underestimated.
scale.3: Most costs included. Channel breakdown present but incomplete. CAC reasonably accurate.
scale.5: Fully-loaded CAC with all costs itemized. Detailed channel-level breakdown. Time-period matching correct.

criteria.name: LTV Methodology Rigor
criteria.description: LTV calculated using cohort data, not averages. Conservative assumptions, observed retention used.

scale.1: LTV based on average retention or unrealistic assumptions (e.g., 5-year LTV with 1 month data). No cohort analysis.
scale.3: LTV uses cohort data for some periods. Assumptions stated but may be optimistic. Retention curves shown.
scale.5: LTV from observed cohort retention. Conservative extrapolation. Multiple cohorts compared. Time horizon justified.

criteria.name: Contribution Margin Accuracy
criteria.description: Contribution margin includes only variable costs (COGS, hosting, fees, support per unit). Fixed costs excluded.

scale.1: Margin calculation includes fixed costs or omits major variable costs. Inaccurate gross margin.
scale.3: Most variable costs included. Some minor costs may be missing. Margin calculation mostly correct.
scale.5: All variable costs identified and quantified. Fixed costs correctly excluded. Margin breakdown clear and accurate.

criteria.name: Cohort Analysis Depth
criteria.description: Retention tracked by cohort (month/channel/segment). Trends analyzed. Cohorts compared.

scale.1: No cohort analysis. Metrics blended across all customers. No retention curves shown.
scale.3: Basic cohort table present. Some cohorts tracked. Trends mentioned but not deeply analyzed.
scale.5: Detailed cohort tables by month and channel. Retention trends analyzed. Cohort comparisons with insights drawn.

criteria.name: Ratio Interpretation
criteria.description: LTV/CAC ratio interpreted with context (benchmarks, stage, industry). Payback period considered alongside ratio.

scale.1: Ratio calculated but not interpreted. No benchmarks provided. Payback period ignored.
scale.3: Ratio interpreted with general benchmarks. Payback mentioned. Some context (stage, industry) considered.
scale.5: Ratio interpreted with stage-appropriate benchmarks. Payback period analyzed. Combined assessment (ratio + payback) informs recommendations.

criteria.name: Channel-Level Analysis
criteria.description: CAC, LTV, and ratios broken down by acquisition channel. Best/worst channels identified.

scale.1: Blended metrics only. No channel breakdown. Cannot identify which channels are profitable.
scale.3: Some channel breakdown provided. Major channels identified. Analysis present but incomplete.
scale.5: Comprehensive channel-level CAC and LTV. All channels compared. Clear identification of best/worst performers with actionable insights.

criteria.name: Sensitivity Analysis
criteria.description: Key assumptions tested (churn, ARPU, CAC, margin). Impact on ratios quantified.

scale.1: No sensitivity analysis. Assumptions not tested. Single-point estimates only.
scale.3: Basic sensitivity on 1-2 variables. Impact direction noted but not quantified. Limited scenarios.
scale.5: Comprehensive sensitivity on key variables (churn, ARPU, CAC, margin). Multiple scenarios. Impact quantified. Breakeven thresholds identified.

criteria.name: Retention vs. Acquisition Balance
criteria.description: Analysis recognizes retention impact on LTV. Recommendations balance reducing CAC with improving retention.

scale.1: Focus solely on CAC reduction. Retention improvements not considered. No churn analysis.
scale.3: Both CAC and retention mentioned. Some churn analysis. Balance between acquisition and retention somewhat considered.
scale.5: Clear recognition that retention drives LTV. Churn impact quantified. Recommendations prioritize retention improvements over pure CAC reduction where appropriate.

criteria.name: Business Model Appropriateness
criteria.description: Analysis matches business model (subscription, transactional, marketplace, freemium, enterprise). Metrics and benchmarks appropriate.

scale.1: Generic analysis not tailored to business model. Wrong metrics or formulas used. Inappropriate benchmarks.
scale.3: Analysis somewhat tailored to business model. Mostly correct metrics. Benchmarks generally appropriate.
scale.5: Analysis fully customized to business model. Correct metrics (MRR/ARR for SaaS, AOV for ecommerce, GMV/take rate for marketplace). Stage and industry-appropriate benchmarks.

criteria.name: Actionability of Recommendations
criteria.description: Clear, specific recommendations on pricing, channels, retention, and growth based on unit economics. Action items with owners/timelines.

scale.1: Vague or generic recommendations. No specific actions. Cannot implement recommendations.
scale.3: Recommendations provided but somewhat generic. Some specific actions. Implementation path unclear.
scale.5: Specific, actionable recommendations (e.g., 'increase price by $10', 'pause paid social', 'implement onboarding checklist'). Clear priorities. Implementation steps outlined.

SaaS Subscription.specific_guidance: Focus on monthly churn, cohort retention curves, ARPU trends, and NRR. Payback <12 months critical for SaaS.

E-commerce / Transactional.specific_guidance: Track AOV, purchase frequency, repeat rate separately from first purchase. Include all COGS, shipping, and payment fees in margin calculation.

common_pitfalls: Not analyzing supply and demand sides separately
Marketplace / Platform.specific_guidance: Analyze both sides of marketplace. Track GMV per user, take rate, liquidity. Consider network effects on retention and growth.

common_pitfalls: Not separating free and paid user economics
Freemium / PLG.specific_guidance: Calculate blended LTV accounting for free user costs and conversion rates. Track free-to-paid conversion by cohort. Measure viral coefficient and payback for organic vs. paid channels.

common_pitfalls: Excluding sales team costs from CAC
Not accounting for long sales cycles in lag
Enterprise / High-Touch Sales.specific_guidance: Include full sales team costs (salaries, tools, overhead). Account for 3-12 month sales cycle lag. Track NRR >110% as key metric. ACV and contract length critical for LTV.

Simple (Single Product, Early Stage).specific_guidance: Focus on getting CAC and LTV directionally correct. Use simple LTV formula with conservative churn estimate. Aim for LTV/CAC >2:1 minimum.

Standard (Multi-Channel, Growth Stage).specific_guidance: Full channel breakdown required. 6-12 months cohort data expected. Sensitivity on churn, CAC, ARPU. Target LTV/CAC >3:1, payback <12 months.

focus_areas: Advanced metrics (NRR, CAC efficiency, cohort trends)
Complex (Multi-Product, Mature).specific_guidance: Full cohort analysis by product, channel, segment. NRR >110% expected. CAC efficiency (Magic Number >1.0). Multi-year LTV projections with sensitivity. Target LTV/CAC >4:1, payback <6 months.

common_failure_modes.name: Underestimated CAC
common_failure_modes.symptom: CAC excludes sales salaries, tools, or overhead. Only includes ad spend.
common_failure_modes.detection: Check if CAC = ad spend รท customers. Ask: 'Are sales team costs included?'
common_failure_modes.fix: Add all S&M costs. Include salaries, benefits, tools, overhead allocation. Recalculate fully-loaded CAC.

common_failure_modes.name: Vanity LTV
common_failure_modes.symptom: LTV projects 3-5 years out with only 1-3 months of retention data. Unrealistic assumptions.
common_failure_modes.detection: Check cohort data availability. If LTV >> observed revenue, likely vanity LTV.
common_failure_modes.fix: Use only observed retention data. For new products, cap LTV projection at 12-18 months max. Be conservative.

common_failure_modes.name: Blended Metrics
common_failure_modes.symptom: Single blended CAC and LTV. No breakdown by channel or cohort. Hides poor-performing channels.
common_failure_modes.detection: Ask: 'What is CAC and LTV by channel?' If not available, blended metrics likely.
common_failure_modes.fix: Break down CAC and LTV by acquisition channel. Identify best and worst performers. Optimize spend accordingly.

common_failure_modes.name: Ignoring Churn
common_failure_modes.symptom: LTV assumes customers stay forever or uses unrealistically low churn. No cohort retention curves.
common_failure_modes.detection: Check if churn rate stated. If LTV formula doesn't include churn or lifetime, likely ignored.
common_failure_modes.fix: Calculate churn from cohort data. Use retention curves to project LTV. Test sensitivity to churn changes.

common_failure_modes.name: Fixed Costs in Margin
common_failure_modes.symptom: Contribution margin includes fixed costs (engineering, rent, admin). Margin too low.
common_failure_modes.detection: Review margin calculation. If <40% for software or <20% for ecommerce, may include fixed costs.
common_failure_modes.fix: Exclude fixed costs. Include only variable costs that scale with each unit (COGS, hosting per user, support per customer, payment fees).

common_failure_modes.name: No Cohort Analysis
common_failure_modes.symptom: Metrics averaged across all customers. No retention curves. Cannot see if newer cohorts perform better/worse.
common_failure_modes.detection: Ask: 'How does retention differ by cohort?' If not tracked, no cohort analysis.
common_failure_modes.fix: Build cohort retention table. Track M0, M1, M3, M6, M12 retention by acquisition month. Identify trends.

common_failure_modes.name: Payback Period Ignored
common_failure_modes.symptom: High LTV/CAC ratio celebrated, but payback >18 months. Cash burn high, growth unsustainable.
common_failure_modes.detection: Check payback calculation. If not mentioned, likely ignored.
common_failure_modes.fix: Calculate payback = CAC รท (monthly revenue ร margin). If >12-18 months, growth will strain cash. Consider raising capital or improving payback.

common_failure_modes.name: No Sensitivity Analysis
common_failure_modes.symptom: Single-point estimates. No testing of assumptions. Fragile economics if assumptions wrong.
common_failure_modes.detection: Ask: 'What if churn increases 2%?' If impact unknown, no sensitivity analysis.
common_failure_modes.fix: Test churn +/- 1-2%, ARPU +/- 10-20%, CAC +/- 10-20%. Quantify impact on LTV/CAC ratio. Identify breakeven thresholds.

common_failure_modes.name: Wrong Business Model Metrics
common_failure_modes.symptom: Using SaaS metrics (MRR, churn) for transactional business. Or marketplace metrics for subscription business. Confusion.
common_failure_modes.detection: Check if metrics match business model. SaaS should have MRR/ARR/churn. Ecommerce should have AOV/frequency. Marketplace should have GMV/take rate.
common_failure_modes.fix: Use business-model-appropriate metrics. SaaS: ARPU, churn, NRR. Transactional: AOV, purchase frequency. Marketplace: GMV, take rate, liquidity.

common_failure_modes.name: No Actionable Recommendations
common_failure_modes.symptom: Analysis ends with metrics. No recommendations on pricing, channels, retention, or growth strategy.
common_failure_modes.detection: Check if recommendations section exists. If analysis only reports metrics without actions, non-actionable.
common_failure_modes.fix: Provide specific recommendations: pricing changes, channel allocation, retention improvements, growth pace. Tie recommendations directly to unit economics findings.
